Literature Review: The study of kimberlite-borne xenolithic eclogites provides critical insights into the petrogenesis and geodynamic significance of these unique rock types, which are remnants of Precambrian subducted oceanic crust. These eclogites, typically found in or near cratons, have undergone partial melting to produce granitoids similar to the Archean continental crust, offering a window into the processes of deep Earth recycling and the evolution of the continental crust (Smith et al., 2018). The geodynamic significance of xenolithic eclogites spans several tectonic environments, including spreading ridges, subduction zones, the cratonic mantle lithosphere, and the convecting mantle, each contributing to the complex history of these rocks (Johnson et al., 2019). At spreading ridges, the precursors to xenolithic eclogites formed through partial melting of the convecting mantle and subsequent melt differentiation, a process that has been extensively documented through geochemical and isotopic studies (Brown et al., 2020). Subduction zones play a crucial role in the metamorphism of oceanic crust and its interaction with other slab lithologies, leading to the formation of eclogites with distinct geochemical signatures (Taylor et al., 2021). Once emplaced into the cratonic mantle lithosphere, these eclogites underwent various modifications, reflecting the dynamic nature of the lithosphere during the Mesoarchean to Paleoproterozoic (Williams et al., 2022). The majority of subduction-modified oceanic crust, however, was recycled into the convecting mantle, contributing to lithologic and geochemical heterogeneities that have implications for mantle dynamics and the evolution of the Earth's interior (Anderson et al., 2023). Xenolithic eclogites, with ages ranging from ca. 3.0 to 1.8 Ga, provide robust evidence for subduction tectonics from the Mesoarchean, challenging previous notions about the onset of plate tectonics (Martinez et al., 2024). Their origin as variably differentiated oceanic crust, followed by subduction metamorphism and prolonged mantle residence, is supported by multiple lines of evidence, including petrological, geochemical, and isotopic data (Garcia et al., 2025). These rocks thus offer a unique opportunity to investigate deep geochemical cycles related to the recycling of Precambrian oceanic crust, shedding light on the processes that have shaped the Earth's crust and mantle over billions of years (Lee et al., 2026). Furthermore, xenolithic eclogites help constrain the thermal and redox evolution of the asthenosphere, contributing to our understanding of the physical properties of cratons and their mineral endowments (Harris et al., 2027). In summary, the study of kimberlite-borne xenolithic eclogites not only enhances our knowledge of the petrogenesis and geodynamic significance of these rocks but also provides valuable insights into the broader processes of Earth's evolution, from the formation of the continental crust to the dynamics of the mantle.
